intro: Abelicea cretica, commonly known as the Cretan bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the island of Crete in Greece. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its bell-shaped, blue or purple flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or limestone soils and thrives in sunny, well-drained environments. Abelicea cretica has narrow, lance-shaped leaves and produces small, clustered flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. It is valued for its ornamental beauty and is often cultivated in gardens with suitable conditions.

It is found in the wild in various habitats across the island, including rocky areas and coastal regions. The plant thrives in dry, sunny conditions and is adapted to the specific climate of the Mediterranean. It is a rare and endemic species, meaning it is found nowhere else in the world. Its native distribution is limited to the southern part of the Greek island of Crete.

It thrives in sandy or gravelly soils near the shoreline, where it can receive ample sunlight and moderate moisture.
